name: Paskoje Miličević Mihov
content:
Paskoje Miličević Mihov (around 1440[1] – 1516) was a Croatian local builder. With the Andrijić brothers, he was active in drawing plans for the urban development of the Republic of Ragusa (today Dubrovnik) in the midst of the turbulent 15th- and 16th-century.
[2]While Michelozzo and Juraj Dalmatinac worked on the fortifications of the Walls of Dubrovnik and Walls of Ston and on sea walls in the Dubrovnik harbours, Miličević was designing plans of the Dubrovnik Dominican Monastery and a mint in Dubrovnik.[3]
 At the Gate of Pile in Dubrovnik, on the western side of the land walls, there is a stone bridge between two Gothic arches, which were designed by the esteemed architect Paskoje Miličević in 1471.[4] He also designed the two bridges to the Revelin Fortress in the 15th century, which explains the similarities between the bridges.[4]
 
 This article about a Croatian architect is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it.
tags: People from the Republic of Ragusa
raw:
The Sponza Palace in Dubrovnik, the work of Paskoje Miličević
Paskoje Miličević Mihov (around 1440[1] – 1516) was a Croatian local builder. With the Andrijić brothers, he was active in drawing plans for the urban development of the Republic of Ragusa (today Dubrovnik) in the midst of the turbulent 15th- and 16th-century.
[2]While Michelozzo and Juraj Dalmatinac worked on the fortifications of the Walls of Dubrovnik and Walls of Ston and on sea walls in the Dubrovnik harbours, Miličević was designing plans of the Dubrovnik Dominican Monastery and a mint in Dubrovnik.[3]
At the Gate of Pile in Dubrovnik, on the western side of the land walls, there is a stone bridge between two Gothic arches, which were designed by the esteemed architect Paskoje Miličević in 1471.[4] He also designed the two bridges to the Revelin Fortress in the 15th century, which explains the similarities between the bridges.[4]
